newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rupee ends steady vs dlr in dull trade.
newsitem.headline: Indian rupee ends steady vs dlr in dull trade.

text.p: The Indian rupee ended Wednesday steady at 35.88/89 against the dollar in dull, low volume trade, dealers said.
"There was some demand (for dollars) in the morning," said a dealer. He said there were small deals at 35.9050, the lowest level the rupee dipped to on Wednesday.
The rupee continued to gain thereafter as both the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) and an influential Calcutta bank continued to abstain from the market, dealers said.
The rupee was not expected to gain beyond 35.88 as the RBI was buying dollars at this level, dealers said.
The six-month annualised forward premium closed at 6.74 percent, marginally up from the previous close of 6.63 percent.
Dealers said both receivers and payers (of premia) continued to play safe because of uncertainties over RBI intervention.
Last week the RBI was active in the swaps market, buying spot August and September dollars ahead of redemption of India Development Bonds on February 14.

"He (RBI) intervened again on Monday," said a dealer at a foreign bank. "Yesterday he made enquiries but did not intervene," he said. "So payers (banks seeking forward cover) are not willing to pay higher premia," he said.
